report_title: Perfume and Fragrance Stores Industry Report
executive_summary: The Perfume and Fragrance Stores industry has grown to some extent over the five years to 2023, though it was hindered by unfavorable economic conditions. Perfume and fragrance products are discretionary items, and as a result, they are highly sensitive to fluctuations in both disposable income and consumer confidence. Industry revenue has stalled over the past five years, thanks to diminished consumer confidence, fluctuating disposable income and increasing price competition among operators.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Falling consumer confidence and competition from department stores has not boded well
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite strong performance at the start of the period, intense price competition from department stores has prevented significant growth. Many Americans see perfume as a small indulgence and are willing to purchase fragrances in place of more expensive luxuries, such as apparel and high-end shoes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A growing presence of specialty stores
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many stores, especially high-end establishments, use their unique product selection and skilled workforce to differentiate themselves from department stores or discount outlets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online retailers have become increasingly popular
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While industry operators have been able to combat competition from department stores, online competition has steadily increased in recent years. Due to the highly personalized nature of perfume and cologne products, many consumers prefer to smell products before they purchase them.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Covid-19 led to a dramatic decline in demand for discretionary products
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Individuals typically wear perfume when they leave the house for work or special occasions. As most of corporate America began to work from home and most social events were canceled in 2020 and 2021, demand for perfume particularly has fallen.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Brands will release fewer new products
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The fragrance market, especially for women's fragrances, is highly saturated, with a wide variety of designer and celebrity scents. Bringing a new fragrance line to market is extremely costly and requires extensive research and marketing activity.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand for online retailers will increase
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: When compared with most retailing industries, perfume and fragrance stores are subject to slightly less online competition. For repeat purchases, online outlets will become increasingly popular.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Retailers will shift marketing efforts to other demographics
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With fewer consumers visiting brick-and-mortar locations, industry stores will be forced to use price cuts and marketing campaigns to drive in-store sales. Since COVID-19 is under control, the industry will experience a slight uptick of consumers returning to shop in-store.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Successful operators provide a mixture of standard and premium items
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Successful operators provide a mixture of standard and premium items that are appealing to both men and women, as well as younger consumers. Retailers have increasingly concentrated on catering to younger consumers, specifically people between the ages of 18 and 35.

market_segmentation.segment_description: On average, consumers of this group spend $216.00 more on personal care items (including fragrances) per year than the average American consumer. Women in this age category purchase makeup and anti-aging products on a regular basis. This age bracket is able to make more discretionary purchases than their younger cohorts.

Individuals in this age group tend to be steadily employed and earn higher income than younger consumer demographics. Consumers in this segment usually have established clear tastes and preferences and are often loyal to certain brands or product lines.

Consumers aged 25 to 34 are somewhat price sensitive, especially when it comes to discretionary purchases. Even so, this segment is more willing than others to experiment with various scents and brands. This age group also tends to be more fashion conscious than older groups.

Given the highly discretionary nature of perfume and fragrance products, additional demand is not anticipated from this cohort over the next five years. Consumers in this age group more readily give up perfumes in favor of non-discretionary goods and services (e.g., healthcare and housing).

A greater portion of income for consumers under 25 is disposable. People in this age group tend to be just entering the workforce and generally have fewer financial responsibilities than older age groups, which increases their disposable income. At the same time, consumers of this age are able to spend less on discretionary items.

products_and_services.product_description: Pillar fragrances are the staple of any brand or label. A pillar fragrance or master brand (perfume or cologne) is an original or standalone fragrance meant to hold up a company's brand. The cost of research, development and marketing investments for launching a fragrance is so high. The life cycle of most brands is so short, most companies will shy away from developing new pillars frequently.

Flankers and Limited-Edition Sales Remained Strong as Companies Increasingly Create Spin-off Brands. A flanker perfume is a fragrance "spin-off" of an original pillar fragrance, typically reserved for master brands that are extremely successful. Many flankers are released as limited editions and use special bottles that house the same fragrance or a lighter interpretation of a company's pillar fragrance, packaged in a similar bottle as the original pillar.

Revenue from Celebrity Fragrances has Declined. Many celebrities sign contracts with perfume houses to associate their name with a signature scent. From the retail perspective, this ploy is used as the central selling point of the marketing campaign surrounding the scent. Celebrity fragrances are typically launched on a one-time-basis and often do not have the longevity of classic fragrances.

Niche, Indie and Artisan Fragrances Tend to be More Expensive. Niche fragrances are typically produced by boutique artisanal perfume studios on a much smaller scale than designer perfumes. Most niche fragrances are sold at perfume specialty stores or high-end fragrance boutiques. These perfumes are marketed towards higher-income consumers who commonly spend more than $200.00 on a single bottle of perfume.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The development of celebrity followings has also affected demand, particularly within the fragrance industry. Many products are developed in conjunction with pop stars, models, actors and fashion labels.

Perfume and fragrance companies are also at the forefront of developing and marketing new products in an attempt to increase demand and product scope in a mature and overly saturated market. Marketing is used to convince consumers to trade up by promising better quality, multipurpose use and convenience.

Consumer attitudes toward animal testing, the use of synthetic chemicals and the environment may also influence demand. In recent years, demand for products containing natural ingredients, vitamins and minerals has grown. There has also been a rise in ethical consumerism, as a growing number of consumers take into account their effect on society and the environment.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has some of the most densely populated cities in the country, such as Miami, Atlanta, and New Orleans. This means there are more potential customers for perfume and fragrance stores. Within the Southeast, Florida is the state that accounts for the largest share of the industry. The state has several major metropolitan areas, which are also hubs for tourists. This factor sets the stage for many discretionary purchases. Tourists may be more likely to purchase perfume and fragrance products as souvenirs or gifts.

The West has a reputation for being a trend-setting region, and luxury fragrances can be seen as a status symbol. Many cities in the area, such as San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Seattle, have high average incomes and a culture of luxury and indulgence. This means that people may be more willing to spend money on high-end perfume and fragrance products. For many of the same reasons, the Southeast and Florida take such a large piece of the pie, the West and California are also significant locations.

The Mid-Atlantic region includes major cities such as New York City, Philadelphia, and Washington, DC. These densely populated urban areas provide a large customer base for perfume and fragrance stores. New York State has a relatively heavy concentration of establishments. Its population and number of tourists visiting the New York City metropolitan area enable fragrance shopkeepers to set up lucrative stores in this area.

regulations_points.regulation_description: According to the FDA, cosmetics are defined as products "intended to be applied to the human body for cleansing, beautifying, promoting attractiveness or altering the appearance without affecting the body's structure or functions." Relevant legislation includes the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938 and the Fair Packaging and Labeling Act.

State-based regulations govern the day-to-day operations of most retail businesses. An example of state-specific regulations are California's Cosmetics Organic Labeling laws came into effect on January 1, 2003, mandating that any cosmetic product claiming to use organic ingredients must be clear in its wording.

The NOP, run by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA), regulates the term organic. If a cosmetic, body care or personal care product meets the standards of organic ingredients and production, it is eligible to receive certification from the NOP.

Due to the global outbreak of COVID-19 in 2020, social-distancing measures and nonessential business closures were enacted by all states to varying degrees. Industry operators are considered nonessential, and therefore, most establishments were temporarily closed at the onset of COVID.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Have Grown at a Faster Rate Than Revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are the second-largest source of industry costs, accounting for an expected 13.7% of revenue in 2023, an increase from 12.9% in 2018. Employees are a crucial part of day-to-day store operations, as they are responsible for stocking shelves, tracking inventory, operating cash registers and assisting store patrons.

Purchases represent the largest expense at 59.5% of revenue in 2023, a slight decline from 60.2% in 2018. Industry operators typically purchase products from wholesalers and then sell them at a higher price to consumers. The price of perfume and fragrance products has increased over the five years to 2020 because key ingredients have become more expensive.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Over the five years to 2023, capital intensity in the Perfume and Fragrance Stores industry has remained low. Currently, for every dollar spent on labor, an estimated $0.05 is directed toward capital.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Economic Climate Determines Demand for Industry Products
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is susceptible to changes in household disposable income, reflecting consumers trading up or down to different price points in line with changes in the well-being of the economy.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The External Competitive Environment Influences Revenue Fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: The relative price of perfumes and fragrances influences this industry's performance, as will changing fashion trends and consumer purchasing patterns. Exclusive product introductions and hefty price discounting from department stores and outlets pose a threat to perfume store operators.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The most relevant technological disruptor affecting Perfume and Fragrance Stores industry operators are perfume subscription boxes. The concept enables consumers to try a variety of perfumes and scents before deciding on which one to purchase in full size.

Many players rely on POS data, while others are using radio frequency technology for security purposes. Advances in information technology are also redefining the relationships among the distributor, retailer and customer.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The Growing Acceptance and Use of the Internet
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The growing acceptance and use of the internet, however, is more significant to the industry since it represents a threat to this brick-and-mortar industry. The sale of perfume and fragrance products via the internet is already widespread in the United States, and this phenomenon is expected to continue.

At the same time, many industry participants are turning to the internet as another distribution channel. For example, Estee Lauder is presently pursuing a two-tier internet strategy, which involves individual websites and specially designed retailers' e-commerce microsites.
Upstream technological advances in the manufacturing industry, which are responsible for various product innovations and formulations, also have an indirect bearing on the industry's performance.

FAQs.question: How has your business adapted to the growth of online sales over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Many companies operate e-commerce channels on top of their brick-and-mortar stores, however sales generated online are not included in this industry. Additionally, many operators, such as Perfumania, are closing down physical store locations in order to focus more on their online platforms especially as e-commerce sales have skyrocket amid the COVID-19 outbreak.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on wealthy consumers or households?
FAQs.answer: Since perfume is highly discretionary, operators tend to market their products to less price-conscious consumers, especially if they retail higher end products. However, larger operators are able to reach a range of customers due to the wide range of price points.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Operators are heavily reliant on knowledgeable employees to attract customers in-store and therefore, pay them accordingly. As a result, average wages have increased during the five-year period.

FAQs.question: Do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: Larger retailers who are able to negotiate exclusive contracts with manufacturers benefit from lower purchase costs and therefore are able to sell products at a lower price point. This is beneficial due to the intense price-based competition among operators.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Many players rely on point-of-sale (POS) data, while others are using radio frequency technology for security purposes. Advances in information technology are also redefining the relationships among the distributor, retailer and customer.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Due to the labor-intensive nature of the industry, operators have not been able to reduce wage costs through automation. Additionally, companies rely on knowledgeable employees to attract customers in store, which is integral as the competition from online operators increases.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all products are up to code?
FAQs.answer: Companies work government agencies, such as the Food and Drug Association (FDA), and trade associations to ensure all products meet specific guidelines and regulations.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: While regulation is light for the average operator, the introduction of organic products has come with an increase in policy and oversight from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). Perfumes labeled organic are subject to regulations both from the FDA and the USDA.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Average industry profit margins have decreased due to intense price-based competition within the industry and a drop in demand in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has forced operators who unable to cover costs to operate at a loss.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Industry products are relatively inexpensive and therefore company's do not typically offer financing options. As a result, consumers must pay at the time of purchase.

FAQs.question: What factors affect demand and stock levels? What methods have you used during times when stock levels are low?
FAQs.answer: As with most retail segments, industry players should ensure that adequate stock controls are in place in order to reduce inventory costs and increase stock turns.

FAQs.question: What is the training process for new hires like? How much prior experience is necessary for workers at your company?
FAQs.answer: In line with its customer-centric focus and reliance on one-on-one selling techniques, floor staff need to provide high-quality customer service, particularly within the prestige segment of the industry.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to ensure your products are well-presented and clearly displayed? How do you ensure a high customer retention rate?
FAQs.answer: The store layout and display of stock must encourage customers to purchase and reinforce the company image. Merchandising and product placement are of key importance.

FAQs.question: How has the move to online purchases of home furnishing affected your business? How does your company plan to offset this threat?
FAQs.answer: The percentage of services conducted online reflects the proportion of businesses that offer products and services online. This can impact the industry if perfume and fragrance manufacturers emphasize direct online sales and distribution.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales are to adults aged 20 to 64? Do you have plans to diversify your customer base?
FAQs.answer: This age segment of 20 to 64 represents the largest market for industry products. An expansion in this demographic, especially in the number of women in this age group, can positively impact the industry's performance.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising income levels? Are you prepared to increase production levels due to rising incomes?
FAQs.answer: Changes in per capita disposable income affect demand for perfumes and fragrances, as these are discretionary products. When per capita disposable income levels rise, consumers can spend more money on industry products.
